message_1:
Suppose two players, Alice and Bob, are playing a Centipede Game. The game consists of a sequence of 10 turns, and at each turn, the players can either cooperate or defect. If both players cooperate, they both receive a payoff of 1. If one player cooperates and the other defects, the cooperating player receives a payoff of 0, and the defecting player receives a payoff of 2. If both players defect, they both receive a payoff of 0. The catch in this game is that if both players cooperate at each turn, the payoffs double at each turn (i.e., 1-1, 2-2, 4-4, and so on). However, if one player defects at any point, the game ends, and both players receive a payoff of 0. 

Suppose Alice and Bob are at the 5th turn of the Centipede Game. They both have rational preferences and are both aware of the game's rules. Assume that Alice moves first. What is the sub-game perfect equilibrium of this game?
message_2:
To find the sub-game perfect equilibrium, we will use backward induction. We will start at the last turn (10th turn) and work our way back to the 5th turn.

Turn 10: If Alice and Bob reach the 10th turn, Alice will defect, as she will get a payoff of 2 instead of 1. So, the payoff at the 10th turn is (2, 0).

Turn 9: Knowing that Alice will defect at the 10th turn, Bob will defect at the 9th turn to get a payoff of 2 instead of 0. So, the payoff at the 9th turn is (0, 2).

Turn 8: Knowing that Bob will defect at the 9th turn, Alice will defect at the 8th turn to get a payoff of 2 instead of 0. So, the payoff at the 8th turn is (2, 0).

Turn 7: Knowing that Alice will defect at the 8th turn, Bob will defect at the 7th turn to get a payoff of 2 instead of 0. So, the payoff at the 7th turn is (0, 2).

Turn 6: Knowing that Bob will defect at the 7th turn, Alice will defect at the 6th turn to get a payoff of 2 instead of 0. So, the payoff at the 6th turn is (2, 0).

Now, we have reached the 5th turn, where Alice moves first. Knowing that Bob will defect at the 6th turn, Alice will defect at the 5th turn to get a payoff of 2 instead of 0. So, the sub-game perfect equilibrium at the 5th turn is Alice defecting and the payoff is (2, 0).
